Process Hazard Analyses and Compliance Audits are also performed on the ammonia refrigeration systems, and these studies have resulted in action items to improve safety at the facility.  The recommendations mainly consist of developing new procedures or updating existing procedures, providing employee training, implementing practices consistent with industry standards, and performing inspections and tests to maintain the integrity of the equipment.  Woodbridge Winery has implemented most of these action items and is moving forward with addressing any remaining outstanding recommendations.  In addition, the facility plans to continue providing employees with a safe work environment through continued training on current policies and procedures, and conducting audits to identify deficiencies and make improvements.

st one of the following:
o	On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or
o	Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.

A review of the facilitys five year accident history showed that there have been no releases of anhydrous ammonia from the refrigeration systems that meet the above criteria.

Emergency Response Program
Woodbridge Winery has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) for the purpose of protecting employees and the surrounding community.  The EAP covers procedures for: 1) evacuating and accounting for visitors and employees, 2) addressing ammonia releases and other foreseeable emergencies that could occur onsite, 3) notifying external agencies and emergency response personnel, and 4) administering first aid measures for ammonia exposure.  Employees are informed of the elements of the EAP and trained in the evacuation procedure.  In the event of an ammonia release, employees will evacuate or shelter-in-place, depending on the nature of the release, and the facility will investigate the issue and contact the fire department for assistance as needed.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Woodbridge Winery reviews the ammonia refrigeration systems for opportunities to improve on system operations and safety. In 2020-2023, the facility completed a refrigeration controls upgrade for Plants 1, 2, and 3, which included the installation of new compressor panels and additional safety systems such ammonia detectors with horns/strobes and emergency stop switches. In 2021, the pressure relief system for all three ammonia systems was modified to include hydrostatic relief valves on the compressor oil coolers and re-seating relief regulators for the transfer pumps associated with the Liquid Transfer Units. These relief devices were installed to provide protection against hydrostatic pressure buildup and rupture of equipment and piping. The facility also installed an ammonia detector with ho

ned to the HPR, while the liquid in LTV2 is pumped to the main high pressure liquid feed header. Liquid transfer is accomplished using hot gas pressure from the compressors and high pressure transfer pumps.

The vapor from SA1 and SA2 is pulled to the compressors, where the pressure and temperature of the gas is increased. Compressor discharge (high stage discharge or hot gas) is sent to the LTVs to facilitate the liquid transfer process and to the condensers, where it is condensed to a high pressure liquid and returned to either the TSV or HPR.

Plant 3
Inventory: 44,866 lbs
Process Description: 
The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of high pressure liquid ammonia from the Thermosyphon Receiver to the compressors (for oil cooling) and to the High Pressure Receiver (HPR). The HPR feeds high pressure liquid to the Glycol Chiller Packages and the wine chillers. 

At each of the Glycol Chiller Packages, liquid ammonia in the surge drum is fed to a glycol plate and frame heat exchanger(s). The liquid in the heat exchanger(s) is partially vaporized as it cools glycol. The liquid/vapor mixture is returned to the glycol chiller surge drum. The vapor in the surge drum is then drawn off the Low Pressure Suction Accumulator. 

At the wine chillers, liquid ammonia partially vaporizes as it absorbs heat from the wine product flowing inside the chiller tubes.  The resulting vapor in the chillers is drawn off to the Low Pressure Suction Accumulator.  

The Low Pressure Suction Accumulator is equipped with a Liquid Transfer Vessel (LTV).  Liquid in the Low Pressure Suction Accumulator is drained to the LTV.  The LTV sends the liquid to the HPR to be reused in the system. Liquid transfer is achieved via hot gas pressure and transfer pump. 

The vapor in the Low Pressure Suction Accumulator is pulled to the compressors, where the pressure and temperature of the vapor is increased.  Compressor discharge (high stage discharge or hot gas) is sent to the LTV to facilitate th

nia transfer pump.  

Pumped liquid from the 3-Pump Low Pressure Receiver is sent to the 700 series jacketed tanks and Wine Chiller 603.  The 2-Pump Low Pressure Receiver pumps low pressure ammonia to the 500 series jacketed tanks.  The liquid ammonia in the chillers and jacketed tanks partially vaporizes as it absorbs heat from product being cooled. The resulting liquid/vapor mixture is returned to the two Low Pressure Receivers.  The vapor in the Low Pressure Receivers is then pulled to the compressors, where the pressure and temperature of the gas is increased.  Compressor discharge (high pressure ammonia vapor, or hot gas) is sent to the condensers, where it is condensed to a high pressure liquid and returned to the TSR and the HPRs.  

The liquid ammonia in the TSR is used to cool the oil in the screw compressors.  Liquid ammonia flows into the compressor oil cooler vessel and the vapor/liquid mixture is returned back to the TSR.  Excess liquid in the TSR is drained to the HPR.

Plant 2 
Inventory: 104,447 lbs
Process Description: 
The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of high pressure liquid ammonia from the condensers to either the Thermosyphon Receiver (TSV) or to the High Pressure Receiver (HPR). Liquid in the TSV is used thermosyphon oil cooling for Compressors S6-S11. Excess liquid in the TSV is drained to the HPR. 

High pressure liquid is supplied from the HPR to Compressors S3-S5 for liquid injection oil cooling. The HPR also supplies high pressure liquid to the wine chillers and glycol chillers. At the chillers, the liquid ammonia is partially vaporized as it cools the wine product or the glycol. The liquid/vapor mixture from the chillers is returned to two Suction Accumulators (SA1 & SA2) that are each equipped with a Liquid Transfer Vessel (LTV1 & LTV2). The vapor in each accumulator rises to the top to be drawn off to the compressors, while the liquid settles at the bottom and is drained to the associated LTV. The liquid in LTV1 is retur

Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies
Woodbridge Winery has been in operation since 1978.  Since its inception, it has been committed to providing a safe environment to its employees and surrounding communities.  This commitment is reflected in the safety and environmental programs that are implemented at the facility.  For example, written procedures have been created for operating the ammonia refrigeration systems.  Only trained operators are permitted to perform system operations and maintenance.  Woodbridge Winery has also developed a robust maintenance program to ensure the equipment is in good operating condition.  All of these programs are geared towards the prevention of an accidental release at the facility.  In addition, these programs incorporate emergency procedures to mitigate the effects of a release if it does occur.  At such an event, emergency coordinators will assess the situation and notify outside responding agencies as necessary.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
Woodbridge Winery is located at 5950 East Woodbridge Road in Acampo, California.  Ammonia is used as a refrigerant in the facilitys three refrigeration systems (Plants 1, 2, and 3).  The systems provide cooling to glycol and wine product.  The maximum intended inventory of ammonia for each process and a description of how each process operates are as follows.

Plant 1
Inventory: 39,561 lbs
Process Description: 
The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of high pressure liquid ammonia from the condensers to the Thermosyphon Receiver (TSR) and two High Pressure Receivers (HPRs).  Liquid is supplied from the HPRs to two Low Pressure Receivers (3-Pump and 2-Pump), Wine Chillers, and the Glycol Plate & Frame Chiller.  

Associated with 3-Pump Low Pressure Receiver is a Liquid Transfer Vessel, where excess liquid ammonia in the vessel can be routed back to the HPRs via hot gas pressure from the compressors. Liquid transfer is facilitated with a high pressure ammo
